coming back to cost customer also see a big difference when they compare the

a storage hardware so they realize the utilization about 25% to 30% in the

customers that glaciers durability is 11 9s that's a very big number but after

have a bridge to to get to you know an easier way to interpreting that so for
the 11 eyes we ran a simulation it's kind of more cough simulation which simulated the the
drive failures the storage device failures the server failures the networking failure the building failures
the power failure we combine all of that and we ran a simulation that tells us
that you know we get this 11 nines of durability but a lot of customers tell
us hey you know how do I compare that with my tape solution which is traditionally two copies of tape in the
same room or two copies of tape across two different sides that's located probably about 20 to 30 miles apart so
there was one time we worked with a very large studio in in Hollywood it's not hard to guess who we share this you know
durability model and we asked them hey what if you took our model and ran a simulation to calculate the durability
of two copies of tape that you have and a couple days after their solution architect came back and told us that the
for kata thought for the two copies of tape on the same site they estimated a durability of four nines and then for
two copies of tape in two different rooms in two different buildings he estimated the durability to be about
five nines so that was the moment for him and us to realize that glaciers durability is actually seven orders of
magnitude higher than keeping two copies of tape that was a big aha moment for us and for many media customers so just
want to get that point across to help bridge how to think about the number of nines which we use and a number of
copies that you typically use for your archiving solutions another thing that
customer asks ask us is how do you how do you ensure that my data doesn't change over time so again for a lot of
media customers for data preservation customers digital preservation customers the terminology is fix-it
that really means that the content is fixed the content hasn't changed it's stored in the same way that it's
received on day one so so glacier has this built-in fixity check which you run in a background as a
system process we basically sweep all every every customers content to make
sure that the data is not changing and we also reuse redundant copies so that if we detect a potential change which
equates to a corruption a potential corruption we will fix the content using one of the redundant copies so now you
think about this we actually do all of this fix that you check in the background without telling you but we
expose we actually you know expose roll all of that into a single storage price
4.4 cent per gigabyte this is very different than you know doing your own raid configurations on your tapes or

point four cents really includes and what that 11 is mean hopefully you can

we changed it so we launched this new thing called data retrieval tiers so
instead of having only the standard retrieval model which you know you can get data back from three to five hours
we now add two new models because customers felt that three to five hours
is just not fast enough so on the left hand side we added a new expedited
retrieval model which is meant to be meant to be used for emergency retrievals think about a broadcaster
needing to change a last minute a program schedule think about you know Fox you need to change the 5:00 p.m. you
know sports program for for the for the day and they typically only have about one hour to react to that it's an it's

broadcasters have tapes on-site so they also have someone into the next room grab the tape with a

you know five gigs of a video file then they will do some processing packaging and then they'll ship it out so that is

objects back in as little as one to five
minutes obviously you know the larger the you know your file is the longer it's going to take but customers are now
